articles.content:
Virginia Giuffre recounts a lifetime of abuse in her memoir 'Nobody's Girl' 
         By Adriana Gallardo, Leila Fadel 
        
           Updated Thursday, October 23, 2025 • 1:15 PM EDT 
        
        
           Heard on  Morning Edition 
        
      

        
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Before the world knew her name, she was the teen girl in a pink top and shiny jeans embraced at her waist by the now disgraced Prince Andrew's arm. Behind them stood a smiling Ghislaine Maxwell, the longtime partner of the late Jeffrey Epstein. Epstein himself took the photo. Her name was Virginia Roberts Giuffre, one of the most public accusers of abuse by Epstein and the many powerful men Giuffre says she was trafficked to in the early 2000s. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Epstein was convicted in 2008 in Florida on charges related to soliciting prostitution. His 2019 federal sex-trafficking charges were dismissed after his death by suicide while awaiting trial in New York. Maxwell was later convicted of crimes related to the sexual abuse of minors and is serving a 20-year sentence in Texas. Days before the publication of Giuffre's memoir,  Nobody's Girl,  Buckingham Palace released a statement from Prince Andrew. It said he had agreed to give up his title as Duke of York amid fresh scrutiny of the allegations. In  Nobody's Girl , Giuffre says she first met Prince Andrew in 2001 and that he guessed correctly she was then 17 years old. "My daughters are just a little younger than you," she recalls him saying. "He was friendly enough, but still entitled — as if he believed having sex with me was his birthright," she wrote. Prince Andrew has consistently denied Giuffre's accusations. Epstein  reached a financial settlement  with Giuffre in 2009. Prince Andrew  later settled  with Giuffre in 2022. Giuffre died by suicide in April, at age 41, just months before her book's release. Her collaborator on  Nobody's Girl , author and journalist Amy Wallace, and Giuffre's younger brother, Sky Roberts, spoke about the memoir with  Morning Edition's  Leila Fadel. Here are five takeaways from the conversation.  1. Giuffre called her father "the original betrayer" The memoir begins with the abuse Giuffre said started when she was about 7 years old. Before calling out Epstein, Maxwell and their wealthy friends, Wallace said Giuffre wanted to name her "original betrayer." "When we began unpacking all of that, she had always said 'I was abused by a family friend,' and that was true as far as it went, but she had also been abused by her own father," Wallace said. "You have to understand Virginia's history… victims of sexual trafficking are not born, they are made, and they are made by terrible experiences that they have over years." Giuffre was 16 when she met Maxwell at Mar-a-Lago resort, where she worked as a locker room attendant in the spa. "And up to that point, the world that had been revealed to her, was a world in which adult men had sex with young girls, children, and didn't pay the price for it," Wallace added. Giuffre's father denies these accusations. 2. Her "toughest battle" came at home  Giuffre was married for over 20 years and had three children. Near the end of her life, she was estranged from her husband. Her brother said she had begun to speak openly about the domestic abuse she had allegedly experienced over the years. "She fought off Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein, and she was very proud of that with her survivor sister. She wanted to continue that advocacy work. But I would say, the hardest fight of her battle was in her backyard with her husband, and she was a little embarrassed about that, as anybody would be coming forward," Roberts said. Giuffre's husband denies these allegations. 3. Her brothers were by her side before her death in Australia Earlier this year, Giuffre was recovering from a car crash and renal failure. Her brothers traveled to Australia to help care for her. "At one point, we had a jet lined up for her on a tarmac ready to bring her home so she could get medical treatment," Roberts shared. "We were with her in her final couple of weeks. And, you know, I was, I was, I was the one that found my sister." Having displayed so much strength facing the legal and public battles against Epstein and others, her brother says they thought she "would make it through because she'd pulled through so many times before." 4. Giuffre wanted the Epstein files released President Trump has not ruled out a pardon for Maxwell. "Well, I'll take a look at it. I'll speak to the DOJ," Trump  said earlier this month  to a CNN reporter regarding a possible pardon for Maxwell. "I wouldn't consider it or not consider — I don't know anything about it. I will speak to the DOJ." Wallace said those who doubt Maxwell's involvement in the abuse, "will get their answers in this book." "She was not on the sidelines," Wallace said. "She was sexually abusing herself. She was telling girls to sexually service her. She was hurting some of those girls when she was angry at them in a sexual way." Roberts said he was astounded to hear the president's stance on a possible pardon for Maxwell. "At one point he ran his campaign on the fact that he would release these [Epstein] files," Roberts said. "My sister had hope that he would. She was hopeful." 5. Giuffre's story is larger than the narrative of sex abuse Wallace said Epstein was not an anomaly or "some super apex predator," but rather a sign of our times. "This is part of our culture," she said. "Wealthy people, powerful people get to treat people less wealthy terribly," she said. "And I think that's why it resonates beyond sexual abuse. I think people are sick of it." This article discusses suicide. If you or someone you know is struggling or in crisis,  call or text 988, the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline.  The radio version of this interview was produced by Phil Harrell and Taylor Haney. The digital version was edited by Majd Al-Waheidi. 
         
         Transcript 
         LEILA FADEL, HOST:   There's a famous picture that most of the world would recognize. It's of now-disgraced Prince Andrew with his hand around the waist of a teen girl in a pink top and jeans. That was Virginia Roberts Giuffre. As an adult, she was one of the most outspoken survivors of abuse at the hands of Jeffrey Epstein and convicted sex offender Ghislaine Maxwell. Prince Andrew was one of many powerful men that Giuffre says she was trafficked to by the wealthy pair. On Friday, Buckingham Palace released a statement from Prince Andrew. It said he had given up his title as Duke of York amid fresh scrutiny of the allegations, which he has consistently denied. Virginia wrote about this and all she endured in a book called "Nobody's Girl." But before it was published, she died by suicide in the spring. I spoke to Amy Wallace, her collaborator on the book, along with her brother Sky Roberts. And a warning - sexual abuse and suicide come up in our conversation. The book opens with the last email Wallace received from Virginia. AMY WALLACE: She basically just said, in the case of my passing, I need and want this book to be published - not just for me, but for all survivors. FADEL: Sky, you're written about so lovingly. You were her baby brother. You were with her in Australia near the end of her life. What do you want the world to know about your sister? SKY ROBERTS: I look at my sister as a hero. But at a very fundamental level, like, you can tell in that book, like, how loving she was and how much she wanted to kind of protect me in a lot of ways. But then, as she progressed and she got older and became a mother, you know, there's even circumstances where she was protecting her own daughter. And then I think that expanded to her protecting your daughters, because when she held her daughter for the first time, it was like, this can never happen again. FADEL: Amy, I want to talk more about the beginning of the book and her childhood. The book goes back much further, to abuses that she first encountered at - what? - 7 years old? If you could just talk about what it was like for Virginia to write in such detail. WALLACE: Well, I mean, the entire book is an exercise in trying to show her in all her complexity. FADEL: Yes. WALLACE: And when we began unpacking all of that, she had always said, I was abused by a family friend. And that was... FADEL: Yeah. WALLACE: ...True, as far as it went. But she had also been abused by her own father. As we worked on the book, she said, how can I be calling out all these people who came later - Epstein, Maxwell, all of their wealthy and influential friends who she was trafficked to - and not acknowledge or name the original betrayer of me, the original abuser of me? You have to understand Virginia's history, which is a lot of the victims have tragedy in their pasts, to understand that victims of sexual trafficking are not born. They are made. And they are made by a terrible experience that they have over years. And when you understand that Virginia was just 16 years old when she met Ghislaine Maxwell at Mar-a-Lago, where she was working as a $9-an-hour towel girl in the spa. And up to that point, the world that had been revealed to her was a world in which adult men had sex with young girls - children - and didn't pay the price for it. FADEL: Yeah. And when you say her original betrayer, you're referring to her father? WALLACE: Her father. So you have to understand - she didn't believe that if she walked out the door of Epstein's Manhattan townhouse that the world outside was going to be any better to her. FADEL: Yeah. And you note in the book that you reached out to her father. Actually, there's a lot of meticulous reporting done in this, reaching out to everybody she's accused, and he's continued to deny that. Throughout Virginia's pages, she writes about not being believed - about how it made her feel worthless as a child and teen, about the way she was broken down and used. What Virginia didn't write and what came to light later was that she says her husband was physically abusing her. It's something he denies. ROBERTS: Our sister was very transparent with us, especially towards the end of her relationship, about the abuse that she was incurring for 22 years throughout her marriage, on and off. She fought off Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein, and she was very proud of that with her survivor sisters. She wanted to continue that advocacy work. But, like, I would say the hardest fight of her battle was in her backyard with her husband. And she was a little embarrassed about that, as anybody would be coming forward. She's a strong figure. FADEL: At the end of her life, Sky was with her. ROBERTS: She was laughing when we were there 'cause the chickens would chase me around, and we nicknamed one Raptor at one point. (LAUGHTER) ROBERTS: But, yes. We were with her in her final couple of weeks, and... FADEL: Yeah. ROBERTS: You know, I was the one that found my sister. And... FADEL: I'm so sorry, Sky. I didn't know that. ROBERTS: Yeah. It was - you know, I think we all thought she would make it through because she'd pulled through so many times before. FADEL: You know, I've been thinking a lot. The fight around Epstein is not over. Right now there is a battle over the release of more Epstein documents. And then there's the question of whether Ghislaine Maxwell might get a pardon, which is something President Trump has not ruled out. I mean, what are you thinking, Sky, as you see what's happening around Epstein and Maxwell even today and what she would think? ROBERTS: I think it's very important to first start with the fact that this is the president of the United States. And at one point, he ran his campaign on the fact that he would release these files. My sister had hope that he would. WALLACE: Yeah, and I would add to that. Anyone who has any questions about how involved Ghislaine Maxwell was in the actual sexual abuse of girls will get their answers in this book. She was involved. She was not on the sidelines. This is a woman who has never offered any solace or empathy to the people that she hurt or that Epstein hurt. Jeffrey Epstein has been dead for years, but the specter of him lives on. And I'm so grateful for that, frankly, because this didn't die with him. He's not just some super apex predator who was an anomaly. This is part of our culture. Wealthy people, powerful people get to treat people less wealthy terribly. And I think that's why it resonates beyond sexual abuse. I think people are sick of it. FADEL: Amy Wallace and Sky Roberts, thank you so much for speaking with us. WALLACE: Thank you for having us. ROBERTS: Thank you. FADEL: The book "Nobody's Girl" is out this week. It's Virginia Roberts Giuffre's story. If you or someone you know may be considering suicide or is in crisis, call or text 988, the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline. (SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

articles.title: Would You Shave Your Head for Free Movie Tickets? 'Bugonia' Wants to Make a Buzz
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article highlights a viral promotional stunt for the new film 'Bugonia', directed by Yorgos Lanthimos and starring Emma Stone, where attendees at a Culver City theater were offered free movie tickets in exchange for having their heads shaved by a tattooed barber named K.C. This stunt, organized by marketing firm TriplePlay Studios, is part of a broader trend in film promotion that uses outrageous, memorable experiences to generate social media buzz. The stunt echoes past campaigns like 'The Blair Witch Project' and David Lynch’s 'Inland Empire', but is more modern and designed for digital virality. The company, which previously promoted films like 'Smile' and 'The Long Walk', emphasizes creating attention-grabbing, immersive experiences to drive cinema attendance. The film, which opens nationwide on Halloween, is a dark comedy involving a CEO who is mistaken for an alien and subsequently shaved bald, tying the promotional action directly to the film’s theme.
keyTakeAways: The film 'Bugonia' is a dark comedy directed by Yorgos Lanthimos, starring Emma Stone as a CEO who is kidnapped by cousins who believe she is an alien.
A promotional stunt involving head-shaving in exchange for free movie tickets was conducted at the Culver Theater in Culver City, California.
The stunt was organized by TriplePlay Studios, which is known for other viral marketing campaigns like the 'Smile' and 'The Long Walk' promotions.

articles.content:
Would you shave your head for free movie tickets? 'Bugonia' wants to make a buzz 
         By Mandalit del Barco 
        
           Updated Thursday, October 23, 2025 • 11:19 AM EDT 
        
        
           Heard on  Morning Edition 
        
      

         Bugonia  is the latest film by director Yorgos Lanthimos. The dark comedy stars Emma Stone as a high-powered  CEO who gets kidnapped by a pair of cousins convinced she's an alien . In the process, they shave her head bald. The film opens nationwide on October 31, but one audience in Culver City, Calif., was treated to a special advance screening this week. It was part of a publicity stunt. In the lobby of the Culver Theater, a tattooed barber named K.C. shaved heads bald in exchange for free tickets for  Bugonia . First in line was Matt Lopez, a 29-year-old Disneyland ride operator. "Ever since I saw the trailer about six months ago, I'm like 'yeah, I'm definitely down for this,'" he said as his shoulder length brown locks were lopped off. "So if I'm able to see this early and get a free haircut at the same time, it's a no-brainer. Olabisi Kovadel, 29, got her head shaved too. "I can feel some air hitting my scalp right now," she said. "It's pretty refreshing." Over the years, movies have created buzz with other promotional stunts — famously,  a phony documentary  for the 1999 horror movie  The Blair Witch Project . The late director, David Lynch, once campaigned for his movie  Inland Empire  by  chain-smoking on Hollywood Boulevard with a piano and a live cow. The latest stunts are experiences designed to become   viral social media moments. The  Bugonia  promo was set up for Focus Features by TriplePlay Studios, the same company that hyped the creepy, supernatural horror film  Smile  in 2022. "We sent people to  baseball games to sit behind home plate, knowing they'd be on camera, " says Alex Craig, founder of TriplePlay Studios. "They just smiled for the entire baseball game." That whacky marketing stunt put TriplePlay Studios on the map. Last summer, the company plugged the survival thriller  The Long Walk  by  having moviegoers   walk on treadmills continuously  while watching the entire one hour and 48 minute long movie. If they stopped, they were escorted out. Beyond using traditional media, Craig says studios are trying everything they can to get people back to the cinema. "Something that's off the wall and gets the internet's attention," he says. Even if that means getting your head shaved like Emma Stone. 
         
         Transcript

And so if I'm able to see this early and get a free haircut on the same time, it's a no-brainer. DEL BARCO: Twenty-nine-year-old Olabisi Kovadel (ph) got her head shaved, too. OLABISI KOVADEL: Yeah, I can feel some air hitting my scalp right now. It's pretty refreshing. DEL BARCO: Over the years, movies have created buzz with other promotional stunts - famously, a phony documentary for the 1999 horror movie "The Blair Witch Project." articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. government plans to deport Kilmar Abrego Garcia, a Salvadoran national living in Maryland, to Liberia as early as October 31, 2025, following a prior administrative error in which he was mistakenly sent to El Salvador. This move has sparked significant legal and public controversy, with critics arguing it is punitive, unconstitutional, and inhumane, especially given that he has no ties to Liberia and faces criminal charges for human smuggling that he claims are vindictive. A federal judge previously blocked immediate deportation, citing concerns that the government is using the process to punish him. The Department of Homeland Security justifies the deportation by citing Liberia’s democratic status and human rights protections, but attorneys and observers see it as a politically motivated action that undermines immigration justice and humanitarian principles. Alternatives like Costa Rica are being proposed as more humane and lawful options.

articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: This week’s notable book releases feature a bold and genre-defying approach to storytelling, blending memoir, fiction, history, and fantasy. These works, including Ha Jin’s *Looking for Tank Man*, Gish Jen’s *Bad Bad Girl*, Claire Louise-Bennett’s *Big Kiss, Bye-Bye*, Julia Ioffe’s *Motherland: A Feminist History of Modern Russia*, Jaquira Díaz’s *This Is the Only Kingdom*, and Philip Pullman’s *The Rose Field: The Book of Dust, Volume 3*, challenge traditional literary boundaries. While such genre fluidity may seem disruptive, the authors use these hybrid forms to explore deeply personal, political, and cultural themes — such as memory of political repression, mother-daughter relationships, gendered power dynamics in Russia, and the legacy of fantasy literature. The article humorously critiques the erosion of genre distinctions but ultimately celebrates the emotional and intellectual depth these books offer, urging readers to appreciate their innovations while acknowledging the cultural weight behind the labels they once carried.

articles.content:
New books this week dance between genres — and deserve your attention 
         By Colin Dwyer 
        
           Tuesday, October 21, 2025 • 1:03 PM EDT 
        
        
      

         Don't even think about reading these new books — at least, not unless they shape up real quick and start respecting the venerable genre distinctions of our forebears. The last thing we want to do is encourage the kind of troublingly seductive world they represent, in which memoir can just be mixed willy-nilly with fiction, and history, and fantasy and philosophy and … well, you get the idea. We teeter on the cusp of utter madness. Won't somebody  please  think of the genres! OK, I'll admit: I'm being a bit facetious here. All six of the following notable releases do deserve your attention for one reason or another — many, precisely  for  their spry dance with the expectations established by the genres they invoke. But I do ask that, when you pull one of them down and crack it open, you at least spare a thought for the poor, polite label that has been left behind, flaunted and dejected, on the bookshelf where it had stood. Looking for Tank Man , by Ha Jin Jin Xuefei had been in the U.S. for what was to be a temporary stay, pursuing graduate studies after his time in the Chinese army, when tanks rolled into Tiananmen Square in 1989. He never returned to China; he began writing in English as Ha Jin,  condemned Chinese censorship  and claimed several of America's highest regarded  literary prizes . But the violent suppression of student protests at Tiananmen —  his "turning point,"  he told NPR in 2014 — continues to haunt him in his effective exile. In his latest novel, a fictional Chinese graduate student, studying in the U.S. years later, turns her research toward comprehending and coming to terms with the massacre — and reckoning with the urgency of keeping its memory alive. Bad Bad Girl , by Gish Jen  Don't call Jen's new book a memoir, exactly. This gimlet-eyed account of a difficult mother-daughter relationship makes up too much stuff to qualify; but then, to call the book a novel feels misleading too. The book  is  a candid portrait of her relationship with her mother, Agnes, even if it steers more toward emotional truth than factual accuracy. We can leave these questions for the philosophers, or whoever decides the genre tags on Amazon. (Same difference?) The point is, Jen has applied her peculiar set of skills — a candid but big-hearted style once described by  Fresh Air's  Maureen Corrigan as  "Frank Capra-esque"  — to one of the central dramas of her own life. Big Kiss, Bye-Bye , by Claire Louise-Bennett Louise-Bennett's books don't tend to lend themselves to snappy back-cover summaries. Conflict and other traditional fiction-fuels  are  found in them, sure; it's just that those external stimuli often end up feeling secondary to the expansive inner life of her unnamed narrator. In her latest novel, as in  Pond  and  Checkout 19  before it, a snapshot of the action — in this case, a woman reflecting on her memories of a fading relationship and wondering at the nature of love — doesn't exactly scream "page-turner." But when the pages are actually turning, the effect,  as a reviewer explained for NPR , can be "unusual, and so unsettlingly pleasurable." Motherland: A Feminist History of Modern Russia, from Revolution to Autocracy , by Julia Ioffe Now here's another book with no respect for the sanctity of bookshelf labels. The veteran journalist's first book is a mongrel mixed from memoir, history and reportage, in which Ioffe's own memories mingle with archival dives and on-the-ground conversations. What emerges is a portrait of Russia's past and present, viewed from the fluctuating social and legal positions of its women. For what it's worth, the trajectory of their social standing under today's oligarchy doesn't appear particularly positive.  Motherland  is one of just five books that  still stand a chance of winning  this year's National Book Award for nonfiction. This Is the Only Kingdom , by Jaquira Díaz The hardscrabble early years of Díaz's life in Puerto Rico and Miami, veined as they were with poverty, casual peril and a precarious mother-daughter relationship, boasted enough drama to fill a book in their own right — and indeed they did: her first book,  the 2019 memoir  Ordinary Girls . In her second book, Díaz plies her skills in fiction, with a debut novel that spans generations and centers some rather shaky mother-daughter bonds of its own, amid the tumult of the Puerto Rican barrio. The Rose Field: The Book of Dust, Volume 3,  by Philip Pullman It was in the mid-1990s Pullman published  The Golden Compass , his first novel in what became the His Dark Materials trilogy. An all but immediate international sensation, the original trilogy spawned dozens of translations and a veritable host of screen and radio adaptations — and now, just about three decades later, a completed  follow-up trilogy in print .  The Rose Field  answers the cliff-hangers of  its direct predecessor,  The Secret Commonwealth , and puts a bow on this heady, hefty return to Pullman's beguiling world of daemons, witches and armored ursines.

articles.title: Picasso’s Dora Maar Portrait Sells for $37 Million at Paris Auction
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A vivid 1943 portrait of Dora Maar by Picasso, painted during the end of their relationship, sold at auction in Paris for 32 million euros (about $37 million), surpassing expectations and setting the highest price for any artwork at auction in France this year. The painting, part of Picasso’s 'Woman in a Hat' series, had been in private family possession since 1944 and was previously only seen in a black-and-white photograph. Experts praised its vibrant colors and raw condition, with auctioneer Christophe Lucien calling the sale both a commercial and emotional success. The work, while valuable, does not hold the record for the most expensive Picasso painting ever sold — that honor belongs to a version of 'Les Femmes d’Alger' from 2015. The sale reflects global interest in Picasso’s personal relationships and emotional depth, resonating across major art markets including the U.S., Europe, and Asia.
keyTakeAways: A 1943 portrait of Dora Maar by Picasso sold at auction in Paris for 32 million euros, surpassing expectations and setting a record for the highest price paid at auction in France for any artwork this year.
The painting, part of Picasso’s 'Woman in a Hat' series, was painted during a painful end to the artist's relationship with Dora Maar, who was seen as containing tears in the portrait.
The artwork had remained in a private family collection since 1944 and had only been previously seen in a black-and-white photograph, making its vibrant condition a major point of fascination.
The sale was described by auctioneer Christophe Lucien as both a commercial success and an emotional moment, reflecting global interest across major art markets including the U.S., Europe, and Asia.
The sale price, while high, was not the highest ever for a Picasso work — the most expensive being $179.4 million in 2015 for a version of 'Les Femmes d’Alger'.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Melissa poised to become a hurricane and drop torrential rain on Caribbean
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Tropical Storm Melissa, currently near Jamaica and southwest Haiti, is expected to strengthen into a major hurricane with up to 35 inches of rain falling on Haiti’s Tiburon Peninsula and up to 25 inches in Jamaica and the Dominican Republic. Due to its nearly stationary nature, the storm poses a prolonged threat of catastrophic flooding, landslides, and humanitarian crisis, with at least three fatalities reported in Haiti and damage to homes in the Dominican Republic. Authorities in Jamaica, Haiti, and the Dominican Republic have issued emergency warnings, closed schools and government offices, and activated over 650 shelters. The storm is the 13th named system of the Atlantic season, with forecasters warning of a slow-motion disaster that could last for multiple days, raising serious concerns about public safety and infrastructure resilience in vulnerable regions.
keyTakeAways: Tropical Storm Melissa is expected to strengthen into a hurricane and possibly reach Category 4 status by early next week.
Up to 35 inches (89 cm) of rain is forecast for Haiti’s Tiburon Peninsula, and up to 25 inches (64 cm) in Jamaica and southern Haiti and the Dominican Republic.
The storm's slow movement increases the risk of catastrophic flooding and landslides due to saturated ground conditions.
At least three people were killed in Haiti, one in the Dominican Republic, and one reported missing; hundreds of homes are damaged in the Dominican Republic.
Jamaica, Haiti, and the Dominican Republic are under active warnings, with hurricane watches and tropical storm warnings in place.
Over 650 emergency shelters are activated in Jamaica, and all public schools, health centers, and government offices are closed to ensure safety.
The storm is the 13th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, which is predicted to be above normal in storm count.

articles.title: Russian Military Aircraft Briefly Violate Lithuanian Airspace, Sparking NATO Response
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: On October 23, 2025, Russian military aircraft, including a Su-30 fighter and an IL-78 refueling plane, briefly violated Lithuanian airspace, prompting President Gitanas Nausėda to condemn the act as a blatant breach of international law and territorial integrity. Lithuania’s foreign ministry plans to summon Russian embassy representatives in Vilnius to protest. Russia denies the intrusion, claiming the flights were routine training over Kaliningrad in compliance with international rules. The incident is viewed within a broader context of Russian military activity in the Baltic region, raising concerns about hybrid warfare and NATO’s defensive readiness. This event coincides with a key EU summit in Brussels where leaders endorsed the 'Readiness 2030' plan to ensure Europe can defend itself against external threats by the end of the decade. In response, two Spanish fighter jets were scrambled to patrol the area, reinforcing NATO’s collective defense posture.
keyTakeAways: Russian military aircraft briefly violated Lithuanian airspace on October 23, 2025, prompting a strong response from Lithuanian President Gitanas Nausėda.

Russia’s Defense Ministry denies the claim, asserting that Su-30 fighter jets conducting training over Kaliningrad did not enter Lithuanian airspace or violate borders.
Lithuanian armed forces reported that two Russian aircraft (a Su-30 and an IL-78 refueling plane) entered airspace for about 18 seconds, flying approximately 700 meters (765 yards), before exiting.
The incident is linked to broader concerns about Russian military activities in the Baltic region, including drone and air operations, possibly aimed at testing NATO’s defensive readiness.
The event occurs amid heightened regional alertness following Russia’s ongoing aggression in Ukraine and the broader narrative of a hybrid war by Vladimir Putin.
The incident coincides with a key EU summit in Brussels where leaders endorsed the 'Readiness 2030' plan for European defense autonomy by the end of the decade.
Two Spanish fighter jets were scrambled as part of NATO air policing in response to the intrusion, underscoring NATO’s operational readiness in the region.

articles.title: Hispanic Approval of Trump Falls Amid Economic and Immigration Concerns
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A new AP-NORC poll reveals a significant decline in approval of President Donald Trump among Hispanic adults, dropping from 44% in March 2024 to 25% in October 2025. This shift, driven by economic stress, concerns over immigration policies, and a growing perception that the country is moving in the wrong direction, raises concerns for Republicans aiming to maintain support in this key demographic. Despite Trump's economic promises, Hispanic voters report higher financial stress than average, particularly regarding groceries, housing, and health care. Immigration remains a top personal concern for Hispanic adults, with only 25% supporting mass deportations—far below the national average. Within Hispanic Republicans, approval has also declined from 83% to 66%, and younger Hispanics and Hispanic men now hold more negative views. Personal testimonies from individuals like Alejandro Ochoa and Fel Echandi highlight the real-life economic and social toll of Trump’s policies, while the broader trend underscores a growing disconnect between Trump’s campaign messaging and lived experiences of many Hispanic Americans.
keyTakeAways: Hispanic adult approval of Donald Trump has declined from 44% in March 2024 to 25% in October 2025, indicating growing dissatisfaction.
A significant portion of Hispanic adults now believe the country is going in the wrong direction, rising from 63% in March to 73% in October.
Financial stress remains high among Hispanic adults, with more than half citing grocery, housing, and health care costs as major stressors.
Hispanic adults are more likely than other racial groups to view immigration as a personal issue, with about two-thirds prioritizing it.
Support for deporting all undocumented immigrants is lower among Hispanic adults (25%) than among U.S. adults overall (40%), reflecting policy divergence.
Trump’s hardline immigration policies, including mass deportations and crackdowns in Latino neighborhoods, have alienated some Hispanic voters.
Among Hispanic Republicans, approval of Trump has declined from 83% to 66% in the past few months, signaling a weakening of support within this key demographic.
Younger Hispanics and Hispanic men now hold more negative views of Trump, with about two-thirds in both groups viewing him unfavorably, an increase from earlier in the year.

articles.title: Ontario Pauses Anti-Tariff Ads After Trump Ends Trade Talks
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Ontario Premier Doug Ford announced he would pause a taxpayer-funded anti-tariff advertising campaign that used audio from former President Ronald Reagan’s 1987 radio address on trade, following U.S. President Donald Trump’s decision to end all trade negotiations with Canada. Trump accused the ad of being fake and misrepresented, claiming it sought to influence U.S. trade policy and a Supreme Court ruling. Ford argued the ad was authentic and effective, aiming to promote a pro-trade message among Americans, especially during major events like the World Series. Despite criticism from experts and political figures, including McGill professor Daniel Béland, who said the ad backfired, Ford and other Canadian leaders supported continuing the campaign over the weekend. Canadian officials, including Prime Minister Mark Carney, acknowledged the difficulty of navigating U.S. trade policy under Trump but emphasized focusing on export growth to other markets.
keyTakeAways: Ontario Premier Doug Ford announced he would pause an anti-tariff advertising campaign after U.S. President Donald Trump ended trade negotiations with Canada, citing concerns over the impact of the ads on U.S.-Canada relations.

The ads used audio and video of former U.S. President Ronald Reagan’s 1987 radio address on trade to argue against tariffs, with Ford claiming it was a 'real' and effective message from a respected leader.
Trump claimed the ad was fake and misrepresented Reagan’s words, accusing Canada of trying to influence U.S. trade policy and an upcoming Supreme Court ruling.
Trump’s actions escalated trade tensions, prompting Canadian officials to emphasize focusing on what they can control, such as expanding exports to non-U.S. markets.
The Ontario government committed to airing the ads over the weekend, including during the first World Series games between the Toronto Blue Jays and Los Angeles Dodgers.
Canadian political leaders like Manitoba Premier Wab Kinew and British Columbia Premier David Eby supported the ad campaign, calling it effective and impactful.
Political experts and figures like Daniel Béland criticized the ad as having backfired, indicating that it may have intensified diplomatic friction rather than resolving trade disputes.

Former Conservative minister Jason Kenney defended the ad, asserting it accurately represented Reagan’s original message and criticized the Reagan Foundation’s leadership for being influenced by Trump.

articles.title: DOJ Prepares to Send Federal Election Observers to California and New Jersey
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Department of Justice is preparing to send federal election observers to Passaic County, New Jersey, and five California counties (Los Angeles, Orange, Kern, Riverside, and Fresno) ahead of the Nov. 4 off-year elections. The move follows requests from Republican parties in both states, citing concerns about irregularities in vote-by-mail systems and allegations of fraud, especially in politically significant areas like Passaic County and California’s redistricting race. The DOJ claims the monitoring ensures transparency, ballot security, and compliance with federal law, while Democrats and state officials criticize the intervention as politically motivated, lacking legal standing, and potentially an intimidation tactic. The effort comes amid broader national tensions over election integrity, fueled by former President Donald Trump’s repeated false claims about mail-in voting fraud in 2020. Experts argue that the federal government has limited jurisdiction in state-only elections and that observer presence, when limited to non-interaction with voters, does not impact voter outcomes.
keyTakeAways: The U.S. Department of Justice is preparing to send federal election observers to Passaic County, New Jersey, and five California counties (Los Angeles, Orange, Kern, Riverside, and Fresno) ahead of the Nov. 4 off-year elections.
The observers are part of a federal effort to ensure 'transparency, ballot security, and compliance with federal law' in response to requests from Republican state parties.
The focus is on two politically significant races: a governor's race in New Jersey and a special election in California to redraw congressional maps in response to Republican gerrymandering.
California's election includes a redistricting proposition that could add up to five new Democratic House seats, making it a strategic political battleground.

New Jersey's Passaic County, historically Democratic but shifting politically, is targeted due to concerns about vote-by-mail irregularities and allegations of fraud, especially given its significant Latino population.

Democrats and state attorneys general have criticized the DOJ’s involvement as potentially intimidation-based and lacking legal justification, especially since the elections are state-only initiatives with no federal races.
The DOJ has previously sued at least eight states for voter roll information, raising concerns about overreach and the absence of clear legal basis for federal intervention.
The Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, led by Harmeet Dhillon, will oversee the monitoring efforts, with observers working under rules that prohibit interaction with voters or poll workers.

Experts, including former DOJ attorney David Becker, argue that federal intervention in state-only elections is rare and legally limited, with enforcement only possible under civil rights laws preventing racial discrimination.

Historical context includes former President Donald Trump's repeated false claims of election fraud, especially related to mail-in voting, which continues to influence political discourse and federal election oversight.

articles.title: Trump Ends All Trade Negotiations with Canada Over Reagan Ad Controversy
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump terminated all trade negotiations with Canada following a television ad sponsored by Ontario Premier Doug Ford that used a quote from former President Ronald Reagan criticizing tariffs. The ad, which Ford claimed successfully reached U.S. audiences at the highest levels, was accused by Trump of misrepresenting Reagan’s views and being a 'dirty play' aimed at influencing the U.S. Supreme Court on tariffs. The Reagan Presidential Foundation and Institute issued a public statement claiming the ad misrepresented Reagan’s 1987 speech and used unpermitted edits. In response, Trump announced the end of trade talks, citing long-standing frustrations with Canada’s trade strategy, including retaliatory tariffs and a lack of flexibility. Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney expressed openness to continuing talks, but Trump refused to meet with him at the ASEAN summit. The dispute highlights ongoing economic tensions, especially in Canada’s auto sector, and reflects broader political conflicts over trade policy and historical messaging.
keyTakeAways: The ad, sponsored by Ontario’s government, used a quote from Ronald Reagan criticizing tariffs, which Trump claimed misrepresented Reagan’s views and was a deceptive political tactic.
Trump responded by ending all trade negotiations with Canada, citing the ad as an act of 'dirty play' and a betrayal of diplomatic norms.
Ontario Premier Doug Ford initially defended the ad, stating it successfully reached U.S. audiences at the highest levels, but later paused the campaign to allow trade talks to resume.

Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney expressed willingness to continue trade discussions, but Trump refused to meet with him at the ASEAN summit and stated he would leave the trade deal with Canada 'the way it is'.
The Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation and Institute criticized the ad for misrepresenting Reagan's 1987 speech and claimed it used unpermitted edits without authorization.
The ad was paid for by Ontario, not the federal Canadian government, highlighting provincial autonomy in political messaging.
Trump’s decision to terminate negotiations follows years of strained trade relations, including retaliatory tariffs and a history of friction with former Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.
The dispute underscores deeper economic and political tensions, particularly over tariffs, with Canada’s auto sector being significantly impacted by U.S. tariffs and its own retaliatory measures.

articles.title: Trump Pulls Out of Canada Trade Talks Over Alleged Fake Reagan Tariff Ad
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump withdrew from trade negotiations with Canada after accusing Ontario’s provincial government of running a false ad that misrepresented former President Ronald Reagan’s 1987 views on tariffs. The ad falsely suggested Reagan opposed tariffs, when in reality, Reagan criticized trade barriers and emphasized the dangers of protectionism. Historical context reveals that Reagan, despite some protectionist actions, generally opposed tariffs and believed they led to trade wars and market collapse. Trump, in contrast, has aggressively increased U.S. tariffs since his return to office, raising the average tariff rate to 18% — the highest since 1934 — and sparking legal and political debate over executive authority. The Reagan Foundation and other experts have clarified the historical record, asserting the ad misrepresented Reagan’s actual position. The U.S. Supreme Court is set to hear arguments on whether the President has constitutional authority to impose tariffs, deepening the national and international implications of Trump’s trade policies.
keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump withdrew from trade negotiations with Canada, citing a misleading television ad from Ontario that quoted Ronald Reagan's 1987 radio address criticizing tariffs.
The ad misrepresented Reagan’s position on tariffs, as he actually criticized trade barriers and did not favor them, despite some historical exceptions like protecting U.S. industries.
Reagan’s actions in 1987, including tariffs on Japanese semiconductors and motorcycles, show that his trade policy was nuanced and not uniformly protectionist.
Trump’s aggressive use of tariffs — calling himself 'Tariff Man' — has led to significant policy shifts, with the average U.S. tariff rate rising to 18% in 2025, the highest since 1934.
The Canadian ad was criticized as 'fake' by Trump, but the Reagan Foundation confirmed it misrepresented the original context of Reagan’s 1987 speech.
The Supreme Court is scheduled to hear arguments on whether the President has constitutional authority to impose tariffs, raising legal questions about executive power in trade policy.

articles.title: U.S. Stocks Hit Record Highs After Inflation Data Boosts Market Optimism
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: U.S. stock markets surged to record highs on Friday, driven by encouraging inflation data that suggests lower rates may be possible for the Federal Reserve. The S&P 500, Dow Jones, and Nasdaq all set new all-time highs, with the S&P rising 0.8%, the Dow jumping 1%, and the Nasdaq climbing 1.1%. Stronger-than-expected corporate profits from major companies like Ford, Intel, and Google further fueled investor confidence. The AI boom is accelerating demand for computing, with Intel citing AI-driven growth. Google’s stock rose due to an expansion by Anthropic to use Google Cloud for its AI chatbot Claude. Meanwhile, gold prices have declined from a record high, and concerns remain about the U.S. national debt exceeding $38 trillion, which could fuel inflation. Consumer inflation expectations remain mixed, raising concerns about potential inflationary cycles. Market optimism is now centered on the expectation of upcoming Federal Reserve rate cuts to stimulate economic growth and support the job market.
keyTakeAways: U.S. stocks hit record highs after inflation data showed a less painful rise than expected, leading to optimism about future interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.
The S&P 500, Dow Jones, and Nasdaq all set new all-time records, with the S&P rising 0.8%, the Dow jumping 1%, and the Nasdaq climbing 1.1%.

Lower inflation expectations are easing pressure on lower- and middle-income households and may allow the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates to stimulate economic growth and support a slowing job market.
Traders now expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates at its next two meetings, including one next week, due to improved labor market and inflation data.
Stronger-than-expected corporate profits, especially from Ford, Intel, Google (Alphabet), and Procter & Gamble, are boosting investor confidence and stock prices.
The AI boom is driving demand for computing power, with Intel citing increased AI-related demand as a key factor behind its profit surge.
Google's stock rose due to an announcement by Anthropic to expand its use of Google Cloud for AI chatbot Claude, signaling strong AI ecosystem growth.
Gold prices had surged significantly, with Newmont Mining gaining 139% year-to-date, but recent stagnation has sparked concerns about overvaluation and inflation risks.
The U.S. government's gross national debt now exceeds $38 trillion, raising concerns about inflation and long-term economic sustainability.
Consumer inflation expectations remain mixed, according to a University of Michigan report, indicating potential inflationary risks due to behavioral feedback loops.

articles.title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Thousands of residents in Catanduanes, a vulnerable island in the Philippines, have evacuated their homes ahead of Tropical Storm Fengshen, which is expected to bring heavy rainfall and a moderate risk of coastal flooding from waves up to 1.2 meters. The storm's approach follows a pattern of recurring extreme weather events in the region, including recent earthquakes and typhoons, which have already caused significant loss of life and infrastructure damage. The evacuation is part of a repeated drill in Catanduanes, the first major landmass affected by western Pacific cyclones, highlighting both the local preparedness and the broader vulnerability of the Philippines to climate-driven disasters. Scientists warn that increasing storm intensity is linked to human-driven climate change, further emphasizing the need for long-term resilience strategies.
keyTakeAways: Tropical Storm Fengshen is approaching the Philippine island of Catanduanes, prompting over 9,000 residents to evacuate due to predicted coastal flooding and strong winds.
The storm brings a 'minimal to moderate risk' of coastal flooding from waves up to 1.2 meters (3.2 feet), posing significant threats to low-lying and landslide-prone areas.
Catanduanes is one of the first landmasses to face cyclones forming in the western Pacific, making it a critical zone for disaster preparedness and response.
The Philippines experiences an average of 20 storms and typhoons annually, often affecting impoverished coastal communities with limited disaster resilience.
Scientists link increasing storm intensity to climate change, suggesting that rising global temperatures are contributing to more powerful tropical systems.

The country is still recovering from recent earthquakes and typhoons, which have resulted in significant loss of life and infrastructure damage, increasing the strain on emergency services and public health systems.
Evacuation efforts in Catanduanes follow a repeated drill pattern, indicating that local authorities have institutionalized disaster response protocols despite recurring threats.

Title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches

Thousands of residents of a Philippine island have fled their homes along the Pacific coast as weather experts warned of coastal flooding ahead of the approach of Tropical Storm Fengshen, rescue officials said.

The eye of the storm was forecast to brush past Catanduanes, an impoverished island of 270,000 people, later on Saturday with gusts of up to 80km/h (50mph).

Fengshen will bring heavy rainfall, along with a “minimal to moderate risk” of coastal flooding from 1.2-metre (3.2-foot) waves being pushed ashore, the government weather service said.

More than 9,000 residents of Catanduanes moved to safer ground, the provincial disaster office said, in an often-repeated drill on the island that has previously been the first major landmass hit by cyclones that form in the western Pacific Ocean.

The Catanduanes provincial government ordered local officials to “activate their respective evacuation plans” for residents of “high-risk areas”, including the coast, low-lying communities and landslide-prone slopes, rescue official Gerry Rubio told the AFP news agency.

The Philippines is hit by an average of 20 storms and typhoons each year, striking disaster-prone areas where millions of impoverished people live.

Scientists warn that storms are becoming more powerful as the planet warms due to human-driven climate change.

Fengshen comes as the country is still reeling from a series of major earthquakes and typhoons that killed dozens of people in recent weeks.

Earlier this month, at least 79 people were killed in a  magnitude 6.9 earthquake  in Cebu province in the central Philippines.

Days later,  another earthquake  struck, this time a magnitude 7.4 off the coast of the southern Philippines, killing at least six people and triggering a second, magnitude 6.9 quake later in the day. Tsunami warnings were issued after each earthquake.

In late September, several people were killed and thousands were evacuated from villages and schools in the northern Philippines, while offices were closed, as Typhoon Ragasa struck.

articles.title: Why has Dutch government taken control of China-owned chipmaker Nexperia?
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Dutch government has taken effective control of the semiconductor company Nexperia, which is owned by Chinese group Wingtech Technology, under the Goods Availability Act due to serious managerial shortcomings under former CEO Zhang Xuezheng. This intervention follows growing geopolitical tensions between China and the West over semiconductor technology, including China's export controls on rare-earth metals and the U.S. extending export restrictions on Chinese-owned tech groups. The Dutch move is aimed at safeguarding critical technological capabilities in Europe, ensuring product continuity, and preventing disruptions to the semiconductor supply chain. While Nexperia maintains confidence in its daily operations and has appointed Stegan Tilger as interim CEO, the situation has drawn criticism from China, which views the action as politically motivated. The European Union is now coordinating with the Netherlands to protect European tech infrastructure amid escalating global trade and security conflicts.
keyTakeAways: The Dutch government took effective control of Nexperia, a semiconductor manufacturer, under the Goods Availability Act due to concerns about managerial mismanagement and threats to European technological security.
Nexperia is owned by Wingtech Technology, a Chinese-owned company, which raised geopolitical concerns given China’s increasing influence in critical tech supply chains.
The intervention was triggered by serious administrative shortcomings under former CEO Zhang Xuezheng, leading to concerns about operational stability and product availability in Europe.
The Dutch government banned Nexperia from relocating assets, firing executives, or making key decisions without approval for one year.
Wingtech was added to the U.S. Entity List in December 2024, increasing pressure on its operations, including those through Nexperia.
China responded with export controls on Nexperia China and subcontractors, further complicating the company’s operations.
The move has drawn criticism from China, which calls it a politically motivated, fact-based security overreach.
Nexperia has appointed Stegan Tilger as interim CEO and maintains confidence in business continuity despite the intervention.
The European Union is coordinating with the Netherlands to safeguard European semiconductor capabilities amid global trade and security tensions.
This incident reflects a broader trend of Western nations restricting Chinese access to advanced technologies and taking regulatory actions to protect critical supply chains.

Title: Why has Dutch government taken control of China-owned chipmaker Nexperia?

The Dutch government has intervened to take effective control of technology group Nexperia, which is owned by Chinese group Wingtech Technology.

The decision comes amid a growing rift between China and the West over the development of technology such as computer chips and semiconductors, which are essential components for the manufacture of artificial intelligence (AI) technology.

Here is more about what the Dutch government announced, why and what happens next.

In a statement released on Sunday, the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs said it had invoked the “highly exceptional” Goods Availability Act to intervene and take control of Nexperia on September 30.

The Goods Availability Act allows the Netherlands to intervene in privately owned companies in exceptional circumstances, such as if the government perceives a threat to the country’s economic security or if it is necessary to ensure that critical goods remain available.

The move followed an emergency hearing by the Dutch Enterprise Chamber on October 7, which concluded that there may be “valid reasons to doubt sound management at Nexperia under the leadership of former CEO Zhang Xuezheng”, a statement from the company said.

The Dutch Enterprise Chamber is a special division of the Amsterdam Court of Appeal, which hears corporate law cases and other matters that could have major social or financial consequences.

In its statement, the government said the intervention had been carried out “due to serious administrative shortcomings” at Nexperia, which “posed a threat to the continuity and safeguarding on Dutch and European soil of crucial technological knowledge and capabilities”.

It claimed that the intervention would ensure Nexperia’s finished and semi-finished products would remain available in case of an emergency.

The ministry added that “losing these capabilities could pose a risk to Dutch and European economic security.”

Following this intervention, it said, “the company’s regular production process can continue.”

However, it added, “Based on the order, decisions within the company can be blocked or reversed if they are (potentially) harmful to the company’s interests, its future as a Dutch and European company, and/or the preservation of this crucial value chain for Europe.”

The statement said that “involved parties” can appeal the decision in court.

Nexperia is a global semiconductor manufacturer headquartered in Nijmegen, the Netherlands. It emerged as a result of electronics group Philips’ purchase of London-based Mullard Radio Valve Company and Hamburg-based Valvo in the 1920s, ultimately forming Philips’ semiconductor operation. In 2006, Philips spun off its semiconductor division, which became NXP Semiconductors, and this was later sold to a consortium of investors led by Beijing Jianguang Asset Management (JAC Capital). Wingtech acquired Nexperia from that consortium for $3.63bn in 2018.

According to its website, Nexperia employs 12,500 people in Europe, Asia and the United States.

Nexperia’s manufacturing site spans more than 80,000 square metres (861,000dsq feet) and has the capacity to build more than 50 billion components annually. It also has sales offices and research-and-development sites in China.

On Tuesday, Nexperia announced that it had suspended Zhang, founder of Wingtech, as a director and removed him as chief executive officer (CEO). It has appointed Stegan Tilger, chief financial officer (CFO), as interim CEO.

“Due to the same serious managerial shortcomings, the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs observed that Nexperia’s operations in Europe were being compromised in an unacceptable manner. This situation raised broader concerns for the Dutch government about the availability of semiconductor products critical to the European industry,” Nexperia’s statement said.

“The combination of Zhang Xuezheng’s behaviour as CEO and (indirect) shareholder, as well as concerns about the semiconductor product availability in the Netherlands and Europe, ultimately led the Dutch government to intervene with an exceptional emergency order on the basis of the Goods Availability Act.”

The statement added that the government’s order has also prohibited Nexperia from relocating company assets, firing existing executives or making important decisions without explicit government approval for one year.

Nexperia said it is confident its daily operations will continue as usual.

On October 9, China  tightened export controls  for critical rare-earth metals, citing national security interests. Foreign companies must now obtain approval from Beijing before they can export the named rare-earth metals or any products that contain them. Exporters must tell the government how the products will be used.

The US is a major consumer of Chinese rare-earth metals, which are critical for its defence industry. Following China’s announcement about new export restrictions, US President Donald Trump responded by  threatening to impose a new 100 percent trade tariff  on China.

Besides being used for the manufacture of smartphones, electric cars and weapons, rare-earth metals are also used in the manufacture of semiconductors, which are essential for the development of artificial intelligence (AI) technology.

The US and its Western allies in Europe have, in recent years, passed regulations restricting China’s access to Western semiconductor technology, fearing that China could reverse-engineer and manufacture the technology, moving ahead in the technological race.

In 2022, former Democratic US President Joe Biden  restricted China’s access  to US semiconductors. The new rules extended restrictions on chipmaking tools being sold to industries which support the semiconductor supply chain. They blocked these industries from accessing US technical expertise, as well as the key components required to build the machines that produce microchips.

The US further tightened these restrictions in October 2023 and, again, in December 2024.

On September 29, 2025, the US Bureau of Industry and Security extended US export control restrictions to all groups which are at least 50 percent-owned by one or more entities on the US Entity List, a list of foreign organisations and companies believed to be participating in, or are at significant risk of participating in, activities that go against US national security or foreign policy interests. These entities are subject to sanctions, export restrictions or licensing requirements. While Nexperia itself is not on the list, Wingtech was added in December 2024.

Then, on October 4, China’s Ministry of Commerce announced export controls preventing Nexperia China and its subcontractors from exporting certain finished components and sub-assemblies made in China.

“Nexperia is actively engaging with the Chinese authorities to obtain an exemption from these restrictions and has deployed all available resources to that end,” the Nexperia statement said.

“While Nexperia has made sufficient preparations to ensure business continuity – and as the BIS rule provides for a 60-day grace period – we are confident that a solution will be found,” Nexperia said in its statement on Tuesday.

Compounding all this, earlier in the year, US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs of 145 percent on Chinese imports to the US. China retaliated with a tariff of 125 percent on US goods. Both countries then reduced their tariffs for 90 days in  May  to allow for trade talks. In August, the two agreed to another 90-day pause, with the most recent round of talks taking place between US and Chinese officials in Spain last month.

But the US has also imposed restrictions on most Chinese cars from being sold in the US. These include high tariffs on Chinese-made electric vehicles.

In addition to its standard 10 percent car import duty, the EU announced last year that it would impose a range of additional tariffs on electric vehicles, from 7.8 percent for Tesla vehicles to 35.3 percent on China’s state-owned SAIC [Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation] vehicles.

Wingtech released a social media statement saying it “firmly opposes the politicisation of commercial matters”.

In the post, it deemed the Dutch government’s move “an excessive intervention based on geopolitical bias rather than a fact-based risk assessment” that is based on the “unfounded pretext of national security”.

Shares in Wingtech have plummeted by 10 percent on the Shanghai Stock Exchange since the announcement. As a result, Wingtech was forced to explain the situation to the exchange, saying that the Dutch government’s decision “temporarily restricts” its control over Nexperia.

Beijing “consistently opposes the overstretching of national security concepts and discriminatory practices targeting companies from specific countries”, Lin Jian, spokesperson for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said on Monday.

“Relevant countries should genuinely uphold market principles and avoid politicising economic and trade issues.”

The European Union has been closely coordinating with Dutch officials and will now work with the Netherlands to decide what to do next to protect important tech capabilities in Europe, according to European Commission spokesperson Olof Gill.

articles.title: Trump’s 100% tariff threat: History of US trade measures against China
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The article details the escalating trade tensions between the United States and China, centered on a recent threat from US President Donald Trump to impose a 100% tariff on Chinese goods in response to China's export controls on rare earth metals. China claims its actions are a justified response to US restrictions on Chinese entities and industries, citing national security concerns and accusing the US of 'double standards'. The dispute follows a long history of trade wars, including past tariff escalations and reciprocal measures, and is seen as a potential flashpoint ahead of a scheduled meeting between Trump and Xi Jinping in South Korea. Experts note that both sides are maintaining escalation tools, with China using strategic, gradual export controls and the US leveraging high tariffs and technology restrictions. The conflict reflects deeper geopolitical competition, where economic interdependence is being weaponized, and the outcome hinges on market reactions and each side’s willingness to bear economic costs.
keyTakeAways: Trump threatened to impose a 100% tariff on Chinese goods in response to China's export controls on rare earth minerals, which are critical for advanced technologies like electric vehicles, smartphones, and semiconductors.

China accused the US of 'double standards' and 'national security abuse' for targeting Chinese entities in sectors like maritime logistics and shipbuilding, arguing that such measures undermine bilateral trade dialogue.
China's expanded export controls on rare earth metals and refining equipment are seen by experts as a pre-meeting strategy to gain leverage in upcoming negotiations with US President Donald Trump.
The US and China have a long history of trade disputes, including past tariff escalations such as a 125% tariff raised to 30% and a 145% tariff raised to 125% followed by a truce.

US policies, especially under Biden, have included strict export controls on semiconductors and advanced chips to China, citing national security concerns, which China counters with its own export restrictions.
The upcoming meeting between Trump and Xi in South Korea is under threat due to escalating tensions, with both sides threatening retaliatory measures.

Experts note that while the US has more economic and technological leverage, China has shown greater strategic organization in its response, using export controls to signal resolve without fully disrupting supply chains.
Both sides are maintaining escalation tools, with the outcome likely influenced more by global market reactions than by diplomatic breakthroughs.
